Simple HTML5 notepad

Here's a little html5 notepad using localStorage. View Demo

line 28 & 30 handle saving and retrieving the localStorage data, It's supported on ie8+ as well as all modern browsers. Works on Android & iPhone too. Lines 32-34 call the save function in 3 different ways to ensure your information is saved automagically (I get a little paranoid like that) Line 5 & lines 20-23 ensure this works on older browsers, but we don't really need most of it so really we could minimize this down to

Which is short enough to be in bookmarklet territory, unfortunately localStorage doesn't work with the local file protocol, the spec says it needs a scheme/host/port to work for security reasons.

Local storage is just too easy NOT to use.

jQuery type effect plugin

Let's kick it old-school, with the absolute CLASSIC typewriter effect. I couldn't find a decent jQuery version of this effect that worked, so I pluginified some vintage javascript.

One little "bug" here is that I'm not handling any dom elements, so the raw html code is displayed while it's writing, but as soon as it's written the dom handles it as elements, you could pre-parse the html and write the elements wholesale but that's far beyond the scope of this simple solution.

If you wanna see the whole shebang check the jsfiddle

04 Oct 2011
[comments]

Better Mobile Redirect

Here is a simple reusable javascript redirect that uses the Mobile Link Discovery Spec which describes a link tag that tells the browser where to find an Alternate for Hand-Held devices: <link href="< Mobile URI >" media="handheld" rel="alternate">. The script is detecting user-agents, which is "evil" but Not every site needs or wants the whole Responsive Design bundle, and that has it's problems. Sometimes you just gotta redirect, try using the link tag with the script below:

Then you'd have html like this:

And away you go... I'm only testing for iPhone, iPad, Android, Blackberry, and WebOs. They run the market right now so I don't feel too bad for leaving out the fray, if you're logging your visitors user agents you can tweak the regex as needed.
